class="sc-1efpnfq-0 ktjMzF">Video Game Actors Are Going On Strike Over AI</h1></header><h2 class="sc-1xcxnn7-0 hrmBxy js_regular-subhead">Generative AI has prompted the first video game industry strike since 2017</h2></div></div><div class="sc-157agsr-0 kQaSNa"><main class="sc-11qwj9y-1 dAHyXr"><div class="sc-11qwj9y-0 iMtYxk"><script type="application/ld+json">{"@type":"NewsArticle","@context":"http://schema.org","url":"https://kotaku.com/voice-actor-strike-sag-aftra-troy-baker-ai-cod-mw-3-1851604153","author":[{"@type":"Person","name":"Ethan Gach"}],"headline":"Video Game Actors Are Going On Strike Over AI","description":"Generative AI has prompted the first video game industry strike since 2017","dateline":"07/25/2024 at 15:24","datePublished":"2024-07-25T15:24:00-04:00","dateModified":"2024-07-26T09:10:00-04:00","mainEntityOfPage":{"@type":"WebPage","url":"https://kotaku.com/voice-actor-strike-sag-aftra-troy-baker-ai-cod-mw-3-1851604153"},"image":{"@type":"ImageObject","height":675,"width":1200,"url":"https://i.kinja-img.com/image/upload/c_fill,h_675,pg_1,q_80,w_1200/7328587e46bb17678da541acb2d63794.png","thumbnail":{"@type":"ImageObject","height":180,"width":320,"url":"https://i.kinja-img.com/image/upload/c_fill,h_180,pg_1,q_80,w_320/7328587e46bb17678da541acb2d63794.png"}},"articleBody":"Video game actors are going on strike for the first time since 2017 after months of negotiations with Activision, Epic Games, and other big publishers and studios over higher pay, better safety measures, and protections from new generative AI technologies. They’ll be hitting the picket line a year after Hollywood actors and writers wrapped up their own historic strikes in an escalation that could have big consequences for the development and marketing of some of the industry’s biggest games.\n\n\nMembers of the Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (SAG-AFTRA) voted last fall to authorize a strike citing an unwillingness of big game companies to budge on guaranteeing performers rights over how their work is used in training AI or creating AI-generated copies. Roughly 2,600 voice actors and motion capture artists, including talents like Troy Baker from The Last of Us, Jennifer Hale from Mass Effect, and Matt Mercer from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, have been working without an Interactive Media Agreement since November 2022. The strike starts on July 26 at 12:01 a.m.\n\n “The video game industry generates billions of dollars in profit annually. The driving force behind that success is the creative people who design and create those games,” chief negotiator  Duncan Crabtree-Ireland said in a statement. “That includes the SAG-AFTRA members who bring memorable and beloved game characters to life, and they deserve and demand the same fundamental protections as performers in film, television, streaming, and music: fair compensation and the right of informed consent for the A.I. use of their faces, voices, and bodies. Frankly, it’s stunning that these video game studios haven’t learned anything from the lessons of last year - that our members can and will stand up and demand fair and equitable treatment with respect to A.I., and the public supports us in that.”\n\n“We are disappointed the union has chosen to walk away when we are so close to a deal, and we remain prepared to resume negotiations, spokesperson Audrey Cooling for the companies involved in the Interactive Media Agreement said in an emailed statement. “We have already found common ground on 24 out of 25 proposals, including historic wage increases and additional safety provisions. Our offer is directly responsive to SAG-AFTRA’s concerns and extends meaningful AI protections that include requiring consent and fair compensation to all performers working under the IMA. These terms are among the strongest in the entertainment industry.”\n\n\nDragon Age and other popular games star union actors\n\n While games set to come out this fall like Dragon Age: The Veilguard, who’s recently revealed voice cast includes several guild members, likely already have their voice and motion-capture work completed, the strike means SAG-AFTRA members would be unavailable for projects that are starting production soon or years out. Games relied much less on actor performances in the past, but most popular franchises are now fully voice-acted, with the biggest-budget productions using motion capture to transfer actors’ real-life performances, frame by frame, into the game. \n\nExactly which games will be impacted remains to be seen. “The language in the IMA is clear that video games that were already in production prior to August 25, 2023, including live service games, are not subject to the strike and remain covered by the ongoing terms of the 2020-2022 IMA,” Cooling said. The guild gives a different threshold of September 2022 for most games, adding that live service games like Fortnite and Apex Legends could be struck starting 60 days from now if things get to that point. \n\n\n\nRead More: Video Game Voice Actors Are Ready To Strike Over AI. Here’s Why\n\nThe last time video game actors went on strike in 2016, it was primarily over pay rates and lasted a entire year. It’s unclear if the strike this time around will be over any sooner. Unlike with the issue of higher pay, people involved in the current negotiations say that the lack of AI protections poses an existential threat to actors and their creative output. Just this week, Wired reported that companies like Activision Blizzard and Riot Games were moving ahead with using generative AI tools to help create concept art and even potentially assets that would make it into finished games like Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3.\n\n “Eighteen months of negotiations have shown us that our employers are not interested in fair, reasonable A.I. protections, but rather flagrant exploitation,” said negotiating committee chair Sarah Elmaleh said in a statement. “We refuse this paradigm—we will not leave any of our members behind, nor will we wait for sufficient protection any longer. We look forward to collaborating with teams on our Interim and Independent contracts, which provide A.I. transparency, consent and compensation to all performers, and to continuing to negotiate in good faith with this bargaining group when they are ready to join us in the world we all deserve.”\n\n SAG-AFTRA video game voice actors are set to hold a panel featuring Ashly Burch (Horizon Forbidden West), Noshir Dala (Red Dead Redemption II), and others at San Diego Comicon later this week on July 26. \n\nUpdate 7/25/2024 3:42 p.m. ET: Added a statement from the game companies. \n\n Update 7/26/2024 9:10 a.m. ET: Added clarification from the companies’ spokesperson and the guild on which games will or won’t be impacted by the strike. \n\n","articleSection":"video game voice actor Television and Radio Artists (SAG-AFTRA) voted last fall to authorize a strike citing an unwillingness of big game companies to budge on guaranteeing performers rights over how their work is used in training AI or creating AI-generated copies. Roughly 2,600 voice actors and motion capture artists, including talents like Troy Baker from <em>The Last of Us</em>, Jennifer Hale from <em>Mass Effect</em>, and Matt Mercer from<em> The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom</em>, have been working without an Interactive Media Agreement since November 2022. The strike starts on July 26 at 12:01 a.m.</p><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 bHUtBb js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div The driving force behind that success is the creative people who design and create those games,” chief negotiator  Duncan Crabtree-Ireland said in a statement. “That includes the SAG-AFTRA members who bring memorable and beloved game characters to life, and they deserve and demand the same fundamental protections as performers in film, television, streaming, and music: fair compensation and the right of informed consent for the A.I. use of their faces, voices, and bodies. Frankly, it’s stunning that these video game studios haven’t learned anything from the lessons of last year - that our members can and will stand up and demand fair and equitable treatment with respect to A.I., and the public supports us in that.”</p><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 bHUtBb js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-4 bNalPz ad-unit ad-mobile"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-0 fjNuCW">Advertisement</div><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile placement-default" data-dfp-site-code="gm.kotaku" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost","postId":"1851604153","blogName":"kotaku","tags":"video game voice actor strike,matt mercer,entertainment culture,epic games,audrey cooling,generative artificial intelligence,troy baker,sag,sarah elmaleh,voice acting,noshir dala,duncan crabtree,ashly burch,artificial intelligence,sag aftra strike,jennifer hale,activision blizzard,video game developer,riot games,aflcio,legend,screen actors guild,american federation of television and radio artists,sag aftra,ai","channel":"culture","section":"news"}"></div><div class="bt-wrapper"><span data-uid="5d260804c9-384" class="bt-uid-tg" style="display:none !important;text-align:center" data-css-selector="ad-container.ad-mobile"></span></div></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-3 bGgkuB kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">“We are disappointed the union has chosen to walk away when we are so close to a deal, and we remain prepared to resume negotiations, spokesperson Audrey Cooling for the companies involved in the Interactive Media Agreement said in an emailed statement. “We have already found common ground on 24 out of 25 proposals, including historic wage increases and additional safety provisions. Our offer is directly responsive to SAG-AFTRA’s concerns and extends meaningful AI protections that include requiring consent and fair compensation to all performers working under the IMA. These terms are among the strongest in the entertainment industry.”<br/></p><div class="sc-v7tysz-0 ilZXoP connatix-main-container"><div id="connatix-mid-article-thumbnails"></div></div><h2 class="sc-1bwb26k-1 dezcon" id="h10273"><a class="js_header-anchor" id=""></a><em>Dragon Age</em> and other popular games star union actors</h2><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv"> While games set to come out this fall like <em>Dragon Age: The Veilguard</em>, who’s <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 erKGZM js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://www.ea.com/en-gb/games/dragon-age/dragon-age-the-veilguard/news/voices-of-the-veilguard",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://www.ea.com/en-gb/games/dragon-age/dragon-age-the-veilguard/news/voices-of-the-veilguard" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer">recently revealed voice cast</a></span> includes several guild members, likely already have their voice and motion-capture work completed, the strike means SAG-AFTRA members would be unavailable for projects that are starting production soon or years out. Games relied much less on actor performances in the past, but most popular franchises are now fully voice-acted, with the biggest-budget productions using motion capture to transfer actors’ real-life performances, frame by frame, into the game. </p><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 bHUtBb js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic ad-mobile-dynamic"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-2 bGgkuB cLmdPT"></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-4 bNalPz ad-unit ad-mobile"><div class="sc-17kx9cd-0 fjNuCW">Advertisement</div><div is="bulbs-dfp" class="ad-container dfp dfp-slot-MOBILE_IN_POST ad-mobile placement-default" data-dfp-site-code="gm.kotaku" data-ad-unit="MOBILE_IN_POST" data-targeting="{"pos":"mobile_inpost","postId":"1851604153","blogName":"kotaku","tags":"video game voice actor strike,matt mercer,entertainment culture,epic games,audrey cooling,generative artificial intelligence,troy baker,sag,sarah elmaleh,voice acting,noshir dala,duncan crabtree,ashly burch,artificial intelligence,sag aftra strike,jennifer hale,activision blizzard,video game developer,riot games,aflcio,legend,screen actors guild,american federation of television and radio artists,sag aftra,ai","channel":"culture","section":"news"}"></div><div class="bt-wrapper"><span data-uid="5d260804c9-384" class="bt-uid-tg" style="display:none !important;text-align:center" data-css-selector="ad-container.ad-mobile"></span></div></div><div class="sc-17kx9cd-1 sc-17kx9cd-3 bGgkuB kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">Exactly which games will be impacted remains to be seen. “The language in the IMA is clear that video games that were already in production prior to August 25, 2023, including live service games, are not subject to the strike and remain covered by the ongoing terms of the 2020-2022 IMA,” Cooling said. The guild gives a different threshold of September 2022 for most games, adding that live service games like <em>Fortnite </em>and<em> Apex Legends</em> could be struck starting 60 days from now if things get to that point. </p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">  <strong>Read More: </strong><span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 erKGZM js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","Internal link","https://kotaku.com/sag-aftra-strike-voice-actor-spider-man-ai-union-1850874117",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://kotaku.com/sag-aftra-strike-voice-actor-spider-man-ai-union-1850874117">Video Game Voice Actors Are Ready To Strike Over AI. Here’s Why</a></span></p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv">The last time video game actors went on <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 erKGZM js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","Internal link","https://kotaku.com/video-game-companies-reach-agreement-to-end-voice-actor-1818762257",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://kotaku.com/video-game-companies-reach-agreement-to-end-voice-actor-1818762257">strike in 2016</a></span>, it was primarily over pay rates and lasted a entire year. It’s unclear if the strike this time around will be over any sooner. Unlike with the issue of higher pay, people involved in the current negotiations say that the lack of AI protections poses an existential threat to actors and their creative output. Just this week, <span><a class="sc-1out364-0 dPMosf sc-145m8ut-0 erKGZM js_link" data-ga="[["Embedded Url","External link","https://www.wired.com/story/ai-is-already-taking-jobs-in-the-video-game-industry/",{"metric25":1}]]" href="https://www.wired.com/story/ai-is-already-taking-jobs-in-the-video-game-industry/" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer"><em>Wired </em>reported</a></span> that companies like Activision Blizzard and Riot Games were moving ahead with using generative AI tools to help create concept art and even potentially assets that would make it into finished games like <em>Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3.</em></p><div class="sc-17kx9cd-5 bHUtBb js_ad-mobile-dynamic js_ad-dynamic kTRrxu"></div></div><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv"> “Eighteen months of negotiations have shown us that our employers are not interested in fair, reasonable A.I. protections, but rather flagrant longer. We look forward to collaborating with teams on our Interim and Independent contracts, which provide A.I. transparency, consent and compensation to all performers, and to continuing to negotiate in good faith with this bargaining group when they are ready to join us in the world we all deserve.”</p><p class="sc-77igqf-0 fnnahv"> SAG-AFTRA video game voice actors are set to hold a panel featuring I had to take it for a ride! The setup at the preview site came complete with fight sticks, transforming my session into a trip down memory lane that I was incredibly grateful for.","type":"Text"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"I’m overjoyed to share that the greatest fighting game of all time is as pristine as it’s ever been. I rolled a few matches against CPUs with my standard team—comprised of Spider-Man, Wolverine, and Akuma—and it was like I never left the sweltering heat of that laundry. The high-quality fight sticks provided during my preview may not have had the same flimsy feeling of the publicly used arcade cabinets, but it was a close enough approximation. I apologize in retrospect to everyone who had the misfortune of having to hear me button mash through those fights, but also god, what a genuine thrill it was to be able to do that again!","type":"Text"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"MvC2 ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"(as well as the other games included in this collection) deserve to be everywhere. Our industry hasn’t always done the greatest job of preserving its own history and ensuring that future generations can experience the classics. Slowly but surely we’re getting better at it, and it’s been heartening to see more publishers and developers re-releasing their own legendary titles as they always should’ve been doing. In the same way that ","type":"Text"},{"reference":"https://kotaku.com/i-cant-stop-buying-resident-evil-4-1831898574","value":[{"styles":[],"value":"Capcom has put ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Resident Evil 4 ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"on every platform imaginable","type":"Text"}],"type":"Link"},{"styles":[],"value":", it should also be porting these arcade games onto anything with a screen.","type":"Text"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"id":"2jBk6rDKork","start":0,"alignment":"Bleed","thumbnail":{"id":"6c1c52c931be44d5b583f483d8e7cd48","format":"jpg"},"caption":[],"type":"YoutubeVideo"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"Porting these titles to modern consoles doesn’t just mean I get to play one of my all-time favorite games on a machine readily available to me. It also means that some great games many folks may never have enjoyed or heard of finally get a spotlight on them. This new collection, which is launching on September 12 digitally and November 22 physically, also touts the first ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel vs Capcom ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"and ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel Super Heroes","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":", which have both enjoyed ports within the last few console generations. However, ","type":"Text"},{"reference":"https://kotaku.com/best-x-men-games-mutant-academy-legends-wolverine-1851489208","value":[{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"X-Men vs. Street Fighter","type":"Text"}],"type":"Link"},{"styles":[],"value":", ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"X-Men: Children of the Atom ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"and ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel vs. Super Heroes ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"are also included, and this will be the first time that any of these three titles will be on consoles outside of their initial releases in the 90s.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"The real draw of this collection seems like it’ll be ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"The Punisher ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"beat-em-up arcade game, which is receiving its first ever official release, aside from the blemished Sega Genesis port that escaped containment. Even if it is the odd man out, since every other one of the included games is a fighting game, it’s a real piece of history and it’s no small miracle that we’ll finally be able to bring home a copy of it.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"As usual, these collections come with a number of added features and modernizations, such as online play and rollback netcode that should make things run as smoothly as possible. Additionally, there are museum-like features cataloging the history of these games with artwork and music from the entire series. Most importantly though, the games play exceptionally well. Not that Capcom has had any issues porting them over in the past, but sometimes these collections are mishandled and butchered. After sampling a number of the games, including dipping my toes into ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"X-Men vs. Street Fighter","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":" for the first time ever, it appears that these titles have been treated with the utmost care and respect.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"appears, on its face, like a slam dunk. Here is a compilation of some of the most well-loved and revered titles of gaming’s youth in a well-considered package delivered by a team that seems aware of its historical significance. I know that I can’t wait to jump back in and be transported back to my own youth, when ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"MvC2 ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"felt like the pinnacle of games and there was no joy greater than getting to duke it out with some of my best friends and one of the most eclectic rosters ever. I had to take it for a ride! The setup at the preview site came complete with fight sticks, transforming my session into a trip down memory lane that I was incredibly grateful for.","type":"Text"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"I’m overjoyed to share that the greatest fighting game of all time is as pristine as it’s ever been. I rolled a few matches against CPUs with my standard team—comprised of Spider-Man, Wolverine, and Akuma—and it was like I never left the sweltering heat of that laundry. The high-quality fight sticks provided during my preview may not have had the same flimsy feeling of the publicly used arcade cabinets, but it was a close enough approximation. I apologize in retrospect to everyone who had the misfortune of having to hear me button mash through those fights, but also god, what a genuine thrill it was to be able to do that again!","type":"Text"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"MvC2 ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"(as well as the other games included in this collection) deserve to be everywhere. Our industry hasn’t always done the greatest job of preserving its own history and ensuring that future generations can experience the classics. Slowly but surely we’re getting better at it, and it’s been heartening to see more publishers and developers re-releasing their own legendary titles as they always should’ve been doing. In the same way that ","type":"Text"},{"reference":"https://kotaku.com/i-cant-stop-buying-resident-evil-4-1831898574","value":[{"styles":[],"value":"Capcom has put ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Resident Evil 4 ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"on every platform imaginable","type":"Text"}],"type":"Link"},{"styles":[],"value":", it should also be porting these arcade games onto anything with a screen.","type":"Text"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"id":"2jBk6rDKork","start":0,"alignment":"Bleed","thumbnail":{"id":"6c1c52c931be44d5b583f483d8e7cd48","format":"jpg"},"caption":[],"type":"YoutubeVideo"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"Porting these titles to modern consoles doesn’t just mean I get to play one of my all-time favorite games on a machine readily available to me. It also means that some great games many folks may never have enjoyed or heard of finally get a spotlight on them. This new collection, which is launching on September 12 digitally and November 22 physically, also touts the first ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel vs Capcom ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"and ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel Super Heroes","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":", which have both enjoyed ports within the last few console generations. However, ","type":"Text"},{"reference":"https://kotaku.com/best-x-men-games-mutant-academy-legends-wolverine-1851489208","value":[{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"X-Men vs. Street Fighter","type":"Text"}],"type":"Link"},{"styles":[],"value":", ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"X-Men: Children of the Atom ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"and ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel vs. Super Heroes ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"are also included, and this will be the first time that any of these three titles will be on consoles outside of their initial releases in the 90s.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"The real draw of this collection seems like it’ll be ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"The Punisher ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"beat-em-up arcade game, which is receiving its first ever official release, aside from the blemished Sega Genesis port that escaped containment. Even if it is the odd man out, since every other one of the included games is a fighting game, it’s a real piece of history and it’s no small miracle that we’ll finally be able to bring home a copy of it.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":[],"value":"As usual, these collections come with a number of added features and modernizations, such as online play and rollback netcode that should make things run as smoothly as possible. Additionally, there are museum-like features cataloging the history of these games with artwork and music from the entire series. Most importantly though, the games play exceptionally well. Not that Capcom has had any issues porting them over in the past, but sometimes these collections are mishandled and butchered. After sampling a number of the games, including dipping my toes into ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"X-Men vs. Street Fighter","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":" for the first time ever, it appears that these titles have been treated with the utmost care and respect.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"},{"containers":[],"value":[{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"Marvel vs. Capcom Fighting Collection: Arcade Classics ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"appears, on its face, like a slam dunk. Here is a compilation of some of the most well-loved and revered titles of gaming’s youth in a well-considered package delivered by a team that seems aware of its historical significance. I know that I can’t wait to jump back in and be transported back to my own youth, when ","type":"Text"},{"styles":["Italic"],"value":"MvC2 ","type":"Text"},{"styles":[],"value":"felt like the pinnacle of games and there was no joy greater than getting to duke it out with some of my best friends and one of the most eclectic rosters ever. It feels so good to be back.","type":"Text"},{"type":"LineBreak"}],"type":"Paragraph"}],"subhead":[{"styles":[],"value":"Capcom’s upcoming arcade classics collection is a glorious trip down memory 							const firstPartyPromise = Promise.resolve(null);
						
						const thirdPartyPromise = new Promise((resolve) => { window._thirdPartyFastToken = resolve });

						const isSuccess = (response) => response && response.meta && response.meta.status === 200;

						const isLoggedIn = (response) => isSuccess(response) && response.data &&
							response.data.token && response.data.token.token && !response.data.token.token.startsWith('dummy-');

						window._user = new Promise((resolve, reject) => {
							Promise.all([firstPartyPromise, thirdPartyPromise]).then(([firstPartyResponse, thirdPartyResponse]) => {

								if (isLoggedIn(firstPartyResponse)) {
									resolve(firstPartyResponse.data);
									return;
								}

								if (isLoggedIn(thirdPartyResponse)) {
									resolve(thirdPartyResponse.data);
									return;
								}

								// Logged out
								if (isSuccess(firstPartyResponse) || isSuccess(thirdPartyResponse)) {
									resolve((firstPartyResponse && firstPartyResponse.data) || (thirdPartyResponse && thirdPartyResponse.data));
									return;
								}

								reject((firstPartyResponse && firstPartyResponse.meta) || (thirdPartyResponse && thirdPartyResponse.meta) || '');
							});
						});
					</script><script src="https://kinja.com/api/profile/accountwithtoken?jsonp=_thirdPartyFastToken&newFollows=true" defer=""></script><script>const pageLoadPromise = new Promise(resolve => {
	// document.readyState cannot be 'complete' here
	window.addEventListener('load', () => {
		const interval = setInterval(() => {
			const timing = performance.getEntriesByType('navigation')[0].toJSON();
			timing.start = performance.timing.requestStart;
			delete timing.serverTiming;
			if (timing.duration > 0) {
				clearInterval(interval);
				resolve(timing.duration);
			}
		}, 100);
	});
});

const onPageLoadOrTimeout = maxTimeout => new Promise(resolve => {
	// Timeout.
	setTimeout(() => { resolve(-1); }, maxTimeout);

	// Load event.
	pageLoadPromise.then(resolve);
});

const copyScript = (s, type) => {
	const script = document.createElement('script');
	script.async = s.async;
	script.defer = s.defer;
	script.innerHTML = s.innerHTML;
	if (s.src) {
		script.src = s.src;
	}
	script.type = type;
	s.remove();
	document.body.appendChild(script);
};

const headScriptsTimeout = 2500;
const minScriptsTimeout = 3500;

// Restore advertisement-related scripts first (within 2.5s).
onPageLoadOrTimeout(headScriptsTimeout).then(() => {
	document.querySelectorAll('script[type="text/defer"].headscript')
		.forEach(s => {
			const type = s.classList.contains('3rdparty') ? 'text/javascript' : 'module';
			copyScript(s, type);
		});

	// Restore public scripts later (in min 3.5s).
	document.querySelectorAll('script[type="text/defer"]')
		.forEach(s => {
			const deferTimeoutAttr = s.getAttribute('data-defer-timeout');
			const deferTimeout = Math.max(parseInt(deferTimeoutAttr) || 0, minScriptsTimeout) - headScriptsTimeout;
			onPageLoadOrTimeout(deferTimeout).then(() => {
				copyScript(s, 'text/javascript');
			});
		});
});
</script></body></html>

readabilityObject.title: Video Game Actors Are Going On Strike Over AI
readabilityObject.content:
Video game actors are going on strike for the first time since 2017 after months of negotiations with Activision, Epic Games, and other big publishers and studios over higher pay, better safety measures, and protections from new generative AI technologies. They’ll be hitting the picket line a year after Hollywood actors and writers wrapped up their own historic strikes in an escalation that could have big consequences for the development and marketing of some of the industry’s biggest games.

Suggested Reading

Oshi No Ko Is An Early Anime Of The Year Contender

  • Off
  • English

Suggested Reading

Members of the Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (SAG-AFTRA) voted last fall to authorize a strike citing an unwillingness of big game companies to budge on guaranteeing performers rights over how their work is used in training AI or creating AI-generated copies. Roughly 2,600 voice actors and motion capture artists, including talents like Troy Baker from The Last of Us, Jennifer Hale from Mass Effect, and Matt Mercer from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, have been working without an Interactive Media Agreement since November 2022. The strike starts on July 26 at 12:01 a.m.

“The video game industry generates billions of dollars in profit annually. The driving force behind that success is the creative people who design and create those games,” chief negotiator Duncan Crabtree-Ireland said in a statement. “That includes the SAG-AFTRA members who bring memorable and beloved game characters to life, and they deserve and demand the same fundamental protections as performers in film, television, streaming, and music: fair compensation and the right of informed consent for the A.I. use of their faces, voices, and bodies. Frankly, it’s stunning that these video game studios haven’t learned anything from the lessons of last year - that our members can and will stand up and demand fair and equitable treatment with respect to A.I., and the public supports us in that.”

“We are disappointed the union has chosen to walk away when we are so close to a deal, and we remain prepared to resume negotiations, spokesperson Audrey Cooling for the companies involved in the Interactive Media Agreement said in an emailed statement. “We have already found common ground on 24 out of 25 proposals, including historic wage increases and additional safety provisions. Our offer is directly responsive to SAG-AFTRA’s concerns and extends meaningful AI protections that include requiring consent and fair compensation to all performers working under the IMA. These terms are among the strongest in the entertainment industry.”

Dragon Age and other popular games star union actors

While games set to come out this fall like Dragon Age: The Veilguard, who’s recently revealed voice cast includes several guild members, likely already have their voice and motion-capture work completed, the strike means SAG-AFTRA members would be unavailable for projects that are starting production soon or years out. Games relied much less on actor performances in the past, but most popular franchises are now fully voice-acted, with the biggest-budget productions using motion capture to transfer actors’ real-life performances, frame by frame, into the game.

Exactly which games will be impacted remains to be seen. “The language in the IMA is clear that video games that were already in production prior to August 25, 2023, including live service games, are not subject to the strike and remain covered by the ongoing terms of the 2020-2022 IMA,” Cooling said. The guild gives a different threshold of September 2022 for most games, adding that live service games like Fortnite and Apex Legends could be struck starting 60 days from now if things get to that point.

Read More: Video Game Voice Actors Are Ready To Strike Over AI. Here’s Why

The last time video game actors went on strike in 2016, it was primarily over pay rates and lasted a entire year. It’s unclear if the strike this time around will be over any sooner. Unlike with the issue of higher pay, people involved in the current negotiations say that the lack of AI protections poses an existential threat to actors and their creative output. Just this week, Wired reported that companies like Activision Blizzard and Riot Games were moving ahead with using generative AI tools to help create concept art and even potentially assets that would make it into finished games like Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3.

“Eighteen months of negotiations have shown us that our employers are not interested in fair, reasonable A.I. protections, but rather flagrant exploitation,” said negotiating committee chair Sarah Elmaleh said in a statement. “We refuse this paradigm—we will not leave any of our members behind, nor will we wait for sufficient protection any longer. We look forward to collaborating with teams on our Interim and Independent contracts, which provide A.I. transparency, consent and compensation to all performers, and to continuing to negotiate in good faith with this bargaining group when they are ready to join us in the world we all deserve.”

SAG-AFTRA video game voice actors are set to hold a panel featuring Ashly Burch (Horizon Forbidden West), Noshir Dala (Red Dead Redemption II), and others at San Diego Comicon later this week on July 26.

Update 7/25/2024 3:42 p.m. ET: Added a statement from the game companies.

Update 7/26/2024 9:10 a.m. ET: Added clarification from the companies’ spokesperson and the guild on which games will or won’t be impacted by the strike.

Members of the Screen Actors Guild-American Federation of Television and Radio Artists (SAG-AFTRA) voted last fall to authorize a strike citing an unwillingness of big game companies to budge on guaranteeing performers rights over how their work is used in training AI or creating AI-generated copies. Roughly 2,600 voice actors and motion capture artists, including talents like Troy Baker from The Last of Us, Jennifer Hale from Mass Effect, and Matt Mercer from The Legend of Zelda: Tears of the Kingdom, have been working without an Interactive Media Agreement since November 2022. The strike starts on July 26 at 12:01 a.m.

 “The video game industry generates billions of dollars in profit annually. The driving force behind that success is the creative people who design and create those games,” chief negotiator  Duncan Crabtree-Ireland said in a statement. “That includes the SAG-AFTRA members who bring memorable and beloved game characters to life, and they deserve and demand the same fundamental protections as performers in film, television, streaming, and music: fair compensation and the right of informed consent for the A.I. use of their faces, voices, and bodies. Frankly, it’s stunning that these video game studios haven’t learned anything from the lessons of last year - that our members can and will stand up and demand fair and equitable treatment with respect to A.I., and the public supports us in that.”

“We are disappointed the union has chosen to walk away when we are so close to a deal, and we remain prepared to resume negotiations, spokesperson Audrey Cooling for the companies involved in the Interactive Media Agreement said in an emailed statement. “We have already found common ground on 24 out of 25 proposals, including historic wage increases and additional safety provisions. Our offer is directly responsive to SAG-AFTRA’s concerns and extends meaningful AI protections that include requiring consent and fair compensation to all performers working under the IMA. These terms are among the strongest in the entertainment industry.”


Dragon Age and other popular games star union actors

 While games set to come out this fall like Dragon Age: The Veilguard, who’s recently revealed voice cast includes several guild members, likely already have their voice and motion-capture work completed, the strike means SAG-AFTRA members would be unavailable for projects that are starting production soon or years out. Games relied much less on actor performances in the past, but most popular franchises are now fully voice-acted, with the biggest-budget productions using motion capture to transfer actors’ real-life performances, frame by frame, into the game. 

Exactly which games will be impacted remains to be seen. “The language in the IMA is clear that video games that were already in production prior to August 25, 2023, including live service games, are not subject to the strike and remain covered by the ongoing terms of the 2020-2022 IMA,” Cooling said. The guild gives a different threshold of September 2022 for most games, adding that live service games like Fortnite and Apex Legends could be struck starting 60 days from now if things get to that point. 



Read More: Video Game Voice Actors Are Ready To Strike Over AI. Here’s Why

The last time video game actors went on strike in 2016, it was primarily over pay rates and lasted a entire year. It’s unclear if the strike this time around will be over any sooner. Unlike with the issue of higher pay, people involved in the current negotiations say that the lack of AI protections poses an existential threat to actors and their creative output. Just this week, Wired reported that companies like Activision Blizzard and Riot Games were moving ahead with using generative AI tools to help create concept art and even potentially assets that would make it into finished games like Call of Duty: Modern Warfare 3.

 “Eighteen months of negotiations have shown us that our employers are not interested in fair, reasonable A.I. protections, but rather flagrant exploitation,” said negotiating committee chair Sarah Elmaleh said in a statement. “We refuse this paradigm—we will not leave any of our members behind, nor will we wait for sufficient protection any longer. We look forward to collaborating with teams on our Interim and Independent contracts, which provide A.I. transparency, consent and compensation to all performers, and to continuing to negotiate in good faith with this bargaining group when they are ready to join us in the world we all deserve.”

 SAG-AFTRA video game voice actors are set to hold a panel featuring Ashly Burch (Horizon Forbidden West), Noshir Dala (Red Dead Redemption II), and others at San Diego Comicon later this week on July 26. 

Update 7/25/2024 3:42 p.m. ET: Added a statement from the game companies. 

 Update 7/26/2024 9:10 a.m. ET: Added clarification from the companies’ spokesperson and the guild on which games will or won’t be impacted by the strike.

metadata.title: Game Actors Are Striking Against EA, Epic, And Others Over AI
metadata.description: Generative AI has prompted the first video game industry strike since 2017
keywords: American Federation of Television and Radio Artists
metadata.firstParagraph: Video game actors are going on strike for the first time since 2017 after months of negotiations with Activision, Epic Games, and other big publishers and studios over higher pay, better safety measures, and protections from new generative AI technologies. They’ll be hitting the picket line a year after Hollywood actors and writers wrapped up their own historic strikes in an escalation that could have big consequences for the development and marketing of some of the industry’s biggest games.
